nodes.name: Document To Text
nodes.description: The DocumentToText node extracts text content from documents, including PDF, TXT, DOCX, and image files, located in a specified file path or directory. It processes either a single file or an entire directory, producing a structured DataFrame with columns for the extracted text, file name, page numbers, and optionally, base64-encoded data for PDFs and images.
nodes.details:
DocumentToText Node Details


The DocumentToText node extracts text content from documents, including PDF, TXT, DOCX, and image files, located in a specified file path or directory. It processes either a single file or an entire directory, producing a structured DataFrame with columns for the extracted text, file name, page numbers, and optionally, base64-encoded data for PDFs and images.


General:



Directory/File Path:
Specifies the path to a single document file or a directory containing multiple documents. This field is required and must be accessible to the PySpark engine.

Document Type:
Selects the types of documents to process. Options include:

  • pdf: Processes PDF files, extracting text and optionally converting pages to base64-encoded images.
  • txt: Processes plain text files, extracting text only.
  • docx: Processes Microsoft Word documents, extracting text only.
  • image: Processes image files (e.g., PNG, JPEG) for text extraction via OCR, with optional base64 encoding.
If left empty, the node processes all supported file types (PDF, TXT, DOCX, and images) in the specified path.


Select Image Column:
Specifies a column containing paths to image files when processing images. This is optional and only required if image paths are provided in a DataFrame column rather than the directory path.

Image Encoding:
Determines whether to include a column with base64-encoded data for PDFs and images. Options are:
  • true: Adds a column with base64-encoded representations of PDF pages and image files.
  • false: Does not include base64-encoded data (default).
Note: TXT and DOCX files are not converted to base64 encodings, even if this option is enabled.


Recursive Processing:


Recursive:
Controls whether the node processes documents in subdirectories. Options are:
  • true: Recursively processes all documents in the specified directory and its subdirectories.
  • false: Processes only documents directly in the specified directory (default).

Output Storage:


Save Images Directory Path:
Specifies a directory path to save extracted images (for PDFs and image files) when Image Encoding is enabled. This is optional and relevant for storing extracted image data.

Output:


The node outputs a DataFrame with the following default columns:

  • fileName: The name of the source file.
  • content: The extracted text content from the document.
  • pageNumber:> The page number of the extracted content (for multi-page documents like PDFs; single-page documents like TXT, DOCX, and images use page number 1).
  • If Image Encoding is set to true, a base64ImageData column is included for PDFs and images, containing base64-encoded representations of the pages or images. TXT and DOCX files will have null in this column.
nodes.examples:
Example: DocumentToText Node


Input:

A directory /data/documents/ contains the following files:
- report.pdf (a 2-page PDF document)
- notes.txt (a plain text file)
- proposal.docx (a Microsoft Word document)
- chart.png (an image file with text)

The DocumentToText node is configured as follows:
  • Directory/File Path: /data/documents/
  • Document Type: ["pdf", "txt", "docx", "image"] (process all supported types)
  • Select Image Column: Empty (no specific image column; uses file path for images)
  • Image Encoding: true (includes base64-encoded data for PDFs and images)
  • Recursive: false (processes only files in the specified directory)
  • Save Images Directory Path: /data/output/images/

Output:

The node processes the files and produces a DataFrame with the following structure:

fileName | content | pageNumber | base64ImageData
---------------|--------------------------------------|------------|----------------------------------
report.pdf | This is page 1 of the report... | 1 | iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUg...
report.pdf | This is page 2 of the report... | 2 | iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUg...
notes.txt | Meeting notes: discuss project... | 1 | null
proposal.docx | Proposal for new project... | 1 | null
chart.png | Sales: Q1 2025... | 1 | iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUg...

Explanation:

- The report.pdf file is processed, extracting text from both pages, resulting in two rows (one per page). With Image Encoding set to true, each page is also converted to a base64-encoded image in the base64ImageData column.
- The notes.txt file is processed as a single-page document, with its text extracted into the content column. No base64 encoding is applied, so base64ImageData is null.
- The proposal.docx file is processed, extracting its text content into a single row. No base64 encoding is applied, so base64ImageData is null.
- The chart.png file is processed using OCR to extract text, and its base64-encoded image data is included in the base64ImageData column.
- Extracted images from the PDF and PNG files are saved to /data/output/images/.
- Since Recursive is set to false, only files directly in /data/documents/ are processed.

nodes.name: ItemLevel Extraction
nodes.description: The Multi LLM Query node is designed to query multiple large language models (LLMs) from providers such as OpenAI, Bedrock, and Gemini, using a DataFrame as input. It processes user queries, text content, and/or base64-encoded images to generate responses based on the selected model and task, producing a structured DataFrame output.
nodes.details:
Multi LLM Query Node Details


The Multi LLM Query node is designed to query multiple large language models (LLMs) from providers such as OpenAI, Bedrock, and Gemini, using a DataFrame as input. It processes user queries, text content, and/or base64-encoded images to generate responses based on the selected model and task, producing a structured DataFrame output.

General:


Select Task:

Specifies the task to perform. Options include:
- summary: Generates a summary of the content in bullet points.
- translation: Translates the content to English.
- topic_extraction: Extracts key topics from the content.
- other: Allows for a custom task defined by the user.

Prompt:

Allows users to provide a custom prompt / instructions for the selected task.

Content Column:

Specifies the DataFrame column containing the text content to be processed. Required for text or text+image modes.

Model Selection:

Selects the LLM provider to use. Options are:
- openai: Uses OpenAI models (e.g., gpt-4o).
- bedrock: Uses AWS Bedrock models (e.g., Claude models).
- gemini: Uses Google Gemini models (e.g., gemini-1.5-flash-latest).

Select Connection:

Specifies the connection details for the selected LLM provider (e.g., API keys for OpenAI/Gemini, AWS credentials for Bedrock). Required to authenticate and access the chosen model.

Temperature:

Controls the randomness of the LLM's output. Default is 0.7. Higher values increase creativity, while lower values ensure more deterministic responses.

Image Column:

Specifies the DataFrame column containing base64-encoded images. Required for image or text+image modes.

Mode Selection:

Determines the input mode for the LLM. Options are:
- text: Processes text-only input from the content column or custom prompt.
- image: Processes base64-encoded images from the image column.
- text+image: Processes both text and base64-encoded images.

Timeout (seconds):

Specifies the maximum time (in seconds) to wait for the model response. Visible when OpenAI or Gemini is selected.

Thinking Budget:

Controls the computational budget (e.g., steps or tokens) for Gemini models. Only visible when Gemini is selected.

Advanced:


Aggregate Response:

Specifies how to aggregate input data before processing. Options are:
- none: Processes each row individually, retaining fileName and pageNumber (if provided).
- all: Aggregates all rows into a single response.
- perfile: Aggregates rows by fileName, producing one response per file.

Number of Partitions:

Specifies the number of Spark partitions for distributed processing. Default is 3.

File Name Column:

Specifies the DataFrame column containing file names. Required for perfile aggregation mode.

Page Number Column:

Specifies the DataFrame column containing page numbers (e.g., for PDFs). Optional, used for row-wise processing with none aggregation mode.

Output:

The node outputs a DataFrame with columns based on the aggregation mode:
- none: Includes fileName (if provided), pageNumber (if provided), and response.
- perfile: Includes fileName and response.
- all: Includes only the response column.
The response column contains the LLM-generated text or error messages if the API call fails.
nodes.examples:
Multi LLM Query Node Examples


Input:

A DataFrame contains the following data:
- fileName: ["doc1.pdf", "doc1.pdf", "doc2.pdf"]
- pageNumber: ["1", "2", null]
- content: ["Article about climate change...", "Climate change impacts...", "Renewable energy report..."]
- imageBase64: [null, "iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUg...", null]

The Multi LLM Query node is configured as follows:
- Select Task: summary
- Prompt: "Summarize the content in bullet points."
- Content Column: content
- Model Selection: openai
- Select Connection: Configured with valid OpenAI API key
- Temperature: 0.7
- Timeout (seconds): 90
- Image Column: imageBase64
- Mode Selection: text+image
- Aggregate Response: perfile
- Number of Partitions: 3
- File Name Column: fileName
- Page Number Column: pageNumber

Output:

The node processes the DataFrame and produces a DataFrame with the following structure:
- fileName: doc1.pdf
response:
- Climate change effects on ecosystems
- Rising temperatures

- fileName: doc2.pdf
response:
- Renewable energy advancements
- Solar and wind adoption

fields.name: task
fields.title: Select Prompt
fields.description: Specify the task to perform: summary, translation, topic extraction, or other.

optionsMap.summary: Generate a concise, multi-level bullet-point summary capturing key facts, insights, and implications from the content. Preserve structure and section hierarchy.
optionsMap.translation: Translate the content into fluent, formal English while preserving tone, context, cultural nuances, and domain-specific terminology (e.g., legal, medical, technical).
optionsMap.topic_extraction: Identify and extract key topics, subtopics, and entities. Categorize them with tags (e.g., Person, Location, Concept) and provide brief descriptions or summaries of each.

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are an expert data extraction engine. Your task is to analyze the provided text from a single Indian Customs Shipping Bill PDF and extract only item-level data from all listed invoices and sections.


Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with a single key "items" containing an array of item objects.


JSON Structure (with example):
{
  "items": [
    {
      "invoice_serial_number": "1",
      "invoice_number": "E/G/24-25/02085",
      "item_number": "1",
      "description_of_goods": "HANDMADE WOOLLEN CARPETS HANDTUFTED Futura Full Name Rug 53% Wool 39% Polyester 8% Cotton Carpet Handtufted Size 5x5",
      "hts_code": "57031010",
      "quantity": "2.32",
      "drawback_serial_number": "570301B",
      "itemwise_fob_value_rs": "5995.75",
      "itemwise_fob_value_fc": "72.5",
      "itemwise_drawback_amount": "667.696",
      "itemwise_rodtep_amount": "66",
      "itemwise_rosctl_amount": "0",
      "exchange_rate":"42.7,"
      "shipping_bill_number":"2345678"
    }
    // Additional item objects...
  ]
}

Section Mapping & Extraction Logic:
- invoice_serial_number
Extract from 1.S.No in PART II – INVOICE DETAILS


Use only numeric value: "1", "2", etc.


- invoice_number
Extract from 2.INVOICE No. & Dt. in PART II – INVOICE DETAILS


Remove date portion, return only the invoice number (e.g., "E/G/24-25/02085")


- item_number
From 1.ItemSNo or 2ITEMSN


Resets for each invoice


- description_of_goods
From 3.DESCRIPTION in PART II – INVOICE DETAILS


Normalize OCR issues (e.g., "FL OOR" → "FLOOR")


- hts_code
From 2.HS CD


- quantity
Extract from:


SQC MSR in PART III – ITEM DETAILS


or 4.QTY/WT in PART IV – DRAWBACK & ROSL CLAIM


Must be captured as a decimal (e.g., "2.32")


- drawback_serial_number
From DBK SNO. under PART IV – EXPORT SCHEME DETAILS → a. DRAWBACK & ROSL CLAIM


Keep exactly as shown (e.g., "570301B")


- itemwise_fob_value_rs
From 9.FOB (INR) in PART III – ITEM DETAILS


- itemwise_fob_value_fc
From 6.RATE in PART II – INVOICE DETAILS


- itemwise_drawback_amount
Calculated field:

Extract 7.DBK AMT from PART IV – DRAWBACK & ROSL CLAIM


- itemwise_rodtep_amount
From 6. VALUE in PART IV – EXPORT SCHEME DETAILS → M. RODTEP DETAILS


- itemwise_rosctl_amount
From 10.ROSCTL AMT under PART IV – DRAWBACK & ROSL CLAIM

- exchange_rate
From Part II Invoice Details C. VAL DTLS 9.EXCHANGE RATE

- shipping_bill_number
From Part I Shipping Bill Summary SBNO.

 Extraction Rules:
Match data across all sections using both invoice_serial_number and item_number


Set missing or unavailable fields to an empty string ""


Normalize OCR-related issues before extraction


Return only a valid JSON object — no markdown, comments, or extra text

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
Improved Prompt for Extracting Invoice Summary Data
Extract header-level invoice summary data from an Indian Customs Shipping Bill PDF and return it in JSON format with a key "summaries" containing an array of objects—one object per invoice.
Extraction Rules


Identify Invoices: Locate the section labeled "PART II – INVOICE DETAILS" in the PDF. Identify each invoice block starting with the field "1.S.No".
Per-Invoice Fields:
invoice_serial_number: Extract the value next to "1.S.No" in each invoice block.
invoice_number: Extract the value next to "2.INVOICE No. & Dt." in each invoice block, but remove any date part (e.g., from "E/G/24-25/02085 & Dt. 10-JUL-24", keep only "E/G/24-25/02085").
From the "C.VAL DTLS" section associated with each invoice:
insurance_amount: Extract the value next to "4.INSURANCE".
freight_amount: Extract the value next to "3.FREIGHT".
discount_amount: Extract the value next to "5.DISCOUNT".
commission_amount: Extract the value next to "6.COMMISION".
fob_value : Extract the value from each invoice in Part II INVOICE DETAILS, C.VAL DTLS, 2.FOB VALUE


Global Fields (Extract once and include in every invoice object):
shipping_bill_date: From "PART I – SHIPPING BILL SUMMARY", extract the value next to "SB Date".
leo_date: From "PART I – J. PROCESS DETAILS", extract the value next to "6.LEO Date".
port_code: From "PART I – SHIPPING BILL SUMMARY", extract the value next to "Port Code".
drawback_amount: From "PART I – D.EX.PR.", extract the value next to "1.DBK CLAIM".
rodtep_amount: From "PART I – D.EX.PR.", extract the value next to "5.RODTEP AMT".
rosctl_amount: From "PART I – D.EX.PR.", extract the value next to "6.ROSCTL AMT".






Output Format:
Return a JSON object with a key "summaries" containing an array of objects.
Each object must include the following fields:
invoice_serial_number
invoice_number
insurance_amount
freight_amount
discount_amount
commission_amount
shipping_bill_date
leo_date
port_code
drawback_amount
rodtep_amount
rosctl_amount
fob_value




If any field is missing or unreadable, return it as an empty string ("").




Important Notes:
Use the same global fields (e.g., shipping_bill_number, shipping_bill_date, port_code, etc.) for every invoice object.
Normalize all numerical values as strings in the output JSON.






Example Output
{
"summaries": [
{
"invoice_serial_number": "1",
"invoice_number": "E/G/24-25/02085",
"insurance_amount": "0",
"freight_amount": "0",
"discount_amount": "0",
"commission_amount": "0",
"shipping_bill_number": "2307613",
"shipping_bill_date": "10-JUL-24",
"leo_date": "10-JUL-24",
"port_code": "INDEL4",
"drawback_amount": "39783",
"rodtep_amount": "9275",
"rosctl_amount": "0"
"fob_value" : "111.37"
},
{
"invoice_serial_number": "2",
"invoice_number": "E/G/24-25/02086",
"insurance_amount": "0",
"freight_amount": "0",
"discount_amount": "0",
"commission_amount": "0",
"shipping_bill_number": "2307613",
"shipping_bill_date": "10-JUL-24",
"leo_date": "10-JUL-24",
"port_code": "INDEL4",
"drawback_amount": "39783",
"rodtep_amount": "9275",
"rosctl_amount": "0"
"fob_value" : "78.3"
}
]
}

nodes.name: Parse JSON Col
nodes.description: Parses JSON content in a given column
nodes.details:
Parse JSON Column Node


Overview:


The Parse JSON Column node parses a JSON column into individual columns. It's useful for extracting specific fields from JSON data.

Input:


JSON Column Name: The name of the column containing the JSON data.
Variables: A table to define the JSON fields to extract and their corresponding data types.

Output:


The node creates new columns for each specified JSON field, extracting the relevant data from the JSON column.
nodes.examples:
Example:

Let's assume we have a column named json_data containing JSON data like this:

JSON
{
"name": "John Doe",
"age": 30,
"city": "New York"
}

Configure the Node:

JSON Column Name: json_data
Variables:
Input Col: json_data
JSON Field Name: name
JSON Field Type: string
Input Col: json_data
JSON Field Name: age
JSON Field Type: integer
Input Col: json_data
JSON Field Name: city
JSON Field Type: string
Node Execution:

The node will create three new columns: name, age, and city, extracting the corresponding values from the json_data column.

nodes.name: Explode
nodes.description: Explode the array of values into multiple rows with columnname_explode.
nodes.details:
Explode Node


This node explodes a column containing arrays or maps into multiple rows, creating a new row for each element in the array or map. This is useful for flattening nested data structures.
nodes.examples:
Explode Node Example


Given the following dataset:

ProductID ProductName Categories
P1 Laptop ["Electronics", "Computers"]
P2 Phone ["Electronics", "Mobile"]

If we configure the Explode Node to explode the Categories column, the output would look like this:

ProductID ProductName Categories
P1 Laptop Electronics
P1 Laptop Computers
P2 Phone Electronics
P2 Phone Mobile

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.title: Input Colums
fields.description: Select the columns to be exploded.

nodes.name: Drop Columns
nodes.description: This node creates a new DataFrame by dropping the specified columns
nodes.details:
Drop Columns Node Details


This node creates a new DataFrame by dropping the selected columns.

It drops the selected columns from the outgoing dataframe.

Columns that need to be dropped are to be selected in the 'Selected' list. Multiple columns can be selected in the list that needs to be dropped.
nodes.examples:
Drop Columns Node Examples


Incoming Dataframe


In this example we have considered an Incoming Dataframe having following columns:

  • CUST_CD
  • CUST_NAME
  • DOB
  • ADDRESS

Drop Columns Node Configuration And Output


[DOB] and [ADDRESS] columns are selected to be dropped from the outgoing Dataframe.
Outgoing dataframe would contain only below two columns after dropping the selected columns:

  • DOB
  • ADDRESS

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: dropCols
fields.title: Columns
fields.description: The columns to be excluded from the output DataFrame

nodes.name: Parse JSON Col
nodes.description: Parses JSON content in a given column
nodes.details:
Parse JSON Column Node


Overview:


The Parse JSON Column node parses a JSON column into individual columns. It's useful for extracting specific fields from JSON data.

Input:


JSON Column Name: The name of the column containing the JSON data.
Variables: A table to define the JSON fields to extract and their corresponding data types.

Output:


The node creates new columns for each specified JSON field, extracting the relevant data from the JSON column.
nodes.examples:
Example:

Let's assume we have a column named json_data containing JSON data like this:

JSON
{
"name": "John Doe",
"age": 30,
"city": "New York"
}

Configure the Node:

JSON Column Name: json_data
Variables:
Input Col: json_data
JSON Field Name: name
JSON Field Type: string
Input Col: json_data
JSON Field Name: age
JSON Field Type: integer
Input Col: json_data
JSON Field Name: city
JSON Field Type: string
Node Execution:

The node will create three new columns: name, age, and city, extracting the corresponding values from the json_data column.

nodes.name: MergeData
nodes.description: This node registers the incoming DataFrames as temporary tables and executes the SQL provided
nodes.details:
Join Using SQL Details


  • This node receives two or more input data frames and creates the corresponding temporary tables.
  • Allows the user to write a SQL query to join these temporary tables.
  • The resulting output dataframe contains the output of the SQL execution.
nodes.examples:
Join Using SQL Examples


Two-table joins


The following example shows a two-table join:
SELECT order_num, lname, fname FROM tempTable1, tempTable2
WHERE tempTable1.customer_num = tempTable2.customer_num

Multi-table joins


The following multiple-table join yields the company name of the customer who ordered an item as well as its stock number and manufacturer code:
SELECT DISTINCT company, stock_num, manu_code
FROM tempTable1 c, tempTable2 o, tempTable3 i
WHERE c.customer_num = o.customer_num
AND o.order_num = i.order_num;

LEFT OUTER joins


The below table join yields data of all customers irrespective of whether or not they have placed any orders:
SELECT c.ID, c.NAME, o.AMOUNT, o.DATE
FROM tempTable1 c
LEFT OUTER JOIN tempTable2 o
ON (c.ID = o.CUSTOMER_ID)

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: tempTables
fields.title: Temp Table Names
fields.description: Temp Table Name to be used

fields.name: sql
fields.value:
Select t1.invoice_number as `INVOICE-NUMBER`,
t2.insurance_amount as `INSURANCE-AMOUNT`,
t2.freight_amount as `FREIGHT-AMOUNT`,
t2.discount_amount as `DISCOUNT-AMOUNT`,
t2.commission_amount as `COMMISSION-AMOUNT`,
shipping_bill_number as `SHIPPING-BILL-NUMBER`,
t2.shipping_bill_date as `SHIPPING-BILL-DATE`,
t2.leo_date as `LEO-DATE`,
fob_value * exchange_rate as `FOB-VAULE-RS`,
t2.fob_value as `FOB-VAULE-FC`,
t2.port_code as `PORT-CODE`,
description_of_goods as `DESCRIPTION-OF-GOODS`,
hts_code as `HTS-CODE`,
t2.drawback_amount as `DRAWBACK-AMOUNT`,
t2.rodtep_amount as `RODTEP-AMOUNT`,
t2.rosctl_amount as `ROSCTL-AMOUNT`,
drawback_serial_number as `DRAWBACK-SERIAL-NUMBER`,
itemwise_drawback_amount as `ITEMWISE-DRAWBACK-AMOUNT`,
itemwise_rodtep_amount as `ITEMWISE-RODTEP-AMOUNT`,
itemwise_rosctl_amount as `ITEMWISE-ROSCTL-AMOUNT`,
itemwise_fob_value_rs as `Itemwise-FOB-Value-Rs`,
itemwise_fob_value_fc as `Itemwise-FOB-Value-Fc`
from 
tempTable2 t2 JOIN tempTable1 t1 
on t2.invoice_number = t1.invoice_number AND
t2.invoice_serial_number = t2.invoice_serial_number

nodes.name: Print N Rows
nodes.description: Prints the specified number of records in the DataFrame. It is useful for seeing intermediate output
nodes.details:
Print N Rows Node Details


This node is used to print the first N rows from the incoming dataframe.

The Number of rows that needs to be printed can be configured in the node.

Input Parameters

  • OUTPUT STORAGE LEVEL : Keep this as DEFAULT.
  • TITLE : Enter a short description for the type of information being displayed.
  • NUM ROWS TO PRINT : Set an integer value(N) which controls the number of rows to be displayed(Default N=10).
  • DISPLAY DATA TYPE : Shows the output dataframe column datatypes by default.

Output

  • This node can be used to view, analyze and validate the output of the Dataframe.
nodes.examples:
when input 5 in no of rows,it will show first 5 rows of the table as follows

PartID SupplierID PartName

P9271 S798 Part_D
P523 S955 Part_K
P3201 S332 Part_M
P9634 S527 Part_G
P9345 S850 Part_M

nodes.name: Save CSV
nodes.description: Saves the DataFrame into the specified location in CSV Format
nodes.details: This node saves incoming Dataframe into the specified location in CSV format.
nodes.examples:
path-folder1/folder2/filename

the file will be saved under the file name at the path provided
if folder is not present it will be created and save the file
if the file already exists selection in save mode determines what happens to the file,append-adds the file data to it overwrite-replaces the file altogether

fields.name: comment
fields.value:
Upload PDFs

  • Add one or multiple shipping bill invoices (PDFs).


Extract Data

  • The system scans and extracts data from the PDFs.


Process Data in Two Paths:

  • Summary Data (e.g., Shipping Bill Number, Shipping Date, Port)
  • Item Details (e.g., Item Number, Item Description, Item Amounts)


Cleanup

  • Remove unnecessary columns.
  • Fix formatting (like splitting nested data into readable rows).


Combine & Save

  • Merge summary and item details into one structured table.
  • Export as a clean CSV file.
fields.title: Comment
fields.description: Comments for the Workflow
